Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of the flu vaccine by stating that it is causing the deadly flu epidemic.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that the flu vaccine is the cause of the deadly flu epidemic.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the flu vaccine is responsible for the deaths of patients who received it, without considering other factors or alternative explanations.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the deadly flu epidemic, such as the presence of a particularly virulent flu strain (H3N2) or the effectiveness of the flu vaccine in a given year.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends getting the flu vaccine every year and maintains that it is largely safe for most people.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on a fake quote from an unnamed "CDC doctor" to support its argument, which undermines its credibility.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the claim.
